Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) Chap.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Emily Johnson, in the above-captioned matter, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws (M.G.L.) Chapter 208, Section 28, and related authority, to modify the current custody and parenting time order concerning the parties’ minor child, Lucas Smith.

*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.proposition: Massachusetts courts, under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, and case law such as *Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 325 (2010), recognize the Court's authority to modify custody and parenting time orders upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child.
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.support_reasoning: The opinion in Charara v. Yatim deals with jurisdiction, comity, and whether to defer to a foreign (Lebanese Jaafarite) custody decree. It does not interpret or apply M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, and it does not discuss modification of existing Massachusetts custody or parenting time orders based on a material and substantial change in circumstances or a best-interests re-evaluation. Instead, it concerns an initial custody determination in a Massachusetts divorce and whether to recognize a prior foreign custody order, so it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard described in the proposition.
*Charara v. Yatim*, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 32.relevant_excerpt: "The best interests of a child is the overarching principle that governs custody disputes in the Commonwealth. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003) ... What is in a child’s best interest depends upon the particular needs of the child, and is left largely to the discretion of the judge, who ‘may consider any factor pertinent to those interests.’ Houston v. Houston, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 529, 535 (2005)."

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time matters (see *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); *Rollins v. Rollins*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 407, 412-13 (2002)).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody matters the central inquiry is what is best for the child, and it applies that standard in determining primary physical custody. Although it does not use the word “paramount,” its description of the “touchstone inquiry” and its focus on weighing all relevant factors to determine the child’s best interests align with the proposition that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in custody and parenting time matters.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (20.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] . . . what is “best for the child” . . . .’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge . . . [whose] findings . . . “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998). However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

*Rollins v. Rollins*, 55 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The best interests of the child are the paramount consideration in all custody and parenting time matters (see *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012); *Rollins v. Rollins*, 55 Mass. App. Ct. 407, 412-13 (2002)).
*Rollins v. Rollins*, 55 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about access to children’s counseling records in a sex-abuse prosecution. It does not concern divorce, custody, or parenting time determinations, nor does it articulate any standard about the ‘best interests of the child’ being paramount in such matters. Accordingly, it does not support the cited family-law proposition and appears to be mis-cited for that point.

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.proposition: The establishment of the child’s stability and routine is critical to determining the child’s best interests (see *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 816 (1981)).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.support_reasoning: The opinion does focus on the child’s best interests in a removal context, but it does not frame those best interests in terms of preserving the child’s existing stability and routine as a critical factor. Instead, the court emphasizes the interrelationship between the child’s best interests and the well-being and opportunities of the custodial parent, and the flexibility of visitation arrangements. The language at page 816 discusses the lack of established criteria for best interests and then adopts factors from D’Onofrio, but it does not single out the child’s stability or routine as a critical or primary consideration.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 8.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts authorities have not discussed in detail the factors to be weighed in deciding questions of removal. The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, set forth in the margin, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). However, the criteria for determining such best interests have, as yet, not been established… We agree that these should include: ‘the prospective advantages of the move in terms of its likely capacity for improving the general quality of life for both the custodial parent and the children….’”}

*Johnson v. Lewis*, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: Massachusetts courts further recognize that age-appropriate parenting schedules and strong parental relationships with both parents are generally in a child’s best interests (see *Johnson v. Lewis*, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (2011); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (2006)).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (.proposition: Massachusetts courts further recognize that age-appropriate parenting schedules and strong parental relationships with both parents are generally in a child’s best interests (see *Johnson v. Lewis*, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 1114 (2011); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (2006)).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (.support_reasoning: The case does not use the exact phrase “age-appropriate parenting schedules,” but its best‑interests analysis in a joint physical custody/removal context emphasizes that shared physical custody is meant to ensure “frequent and continued contact with both parents” and that relocation can be denied where it would significantly reduce one parent’s parenting time. The court notes that when neither parent has a clear majority of custodial time, the child’s interests typically favor protecting relationships with both parents. This aligns with the general proposition that strong relationships with both parents and schedules that preserve such contact are in a child’s best interests.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (.relevant_excerpt: “Shared physical custody contemplates that ‘a child shall have periods of residing with and being under the supervision of each parent . . . assur[ing] . . . frequent and continued contact with both parents.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31… Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’… it is a question for a judge… whether… removal is in a child’s best interests.”

*Beals v. Beals*, 601 Mass. 540 (2006).proposition: *Beals v. Beals*, 601 Mass. 540 (2006), emphasizes the need for the parenting schedule to evolve as the developmental needs of the child change over time.
